sentences: But a federal district court had already issued its own order to the state’s probate judges, instructing them to not deny marriage licenses to   couples.

Moore, throughout the judicial fights over   couples’ marriage rights, had used his role as the administrative head of the state courts to direct probate judges to follow Alabama’s constitutional ban on   couples’ marriages.

A complaint was filed by the Alabama Judicial Inquiry Commission charging Moore with violating judicial ethics in issuing an order in January stating that probate judges in the state “have a ministerial duty not to issue” marriage licenses to   couples.

”   [A guide to Roy Moore, Alabama’s top judge]   A group representing Moore in this case decried the court’s decision as “an unbelievable violation of the law” for suspending the justice through the end of his current term in 2019, noting that he will be unable to seek reelection at that time because of state age restrictions.
”To suspend Chief Justice Moore for the duration of his term is a miscarriage of justice and we will appeal this case to the Alabama Supreme Court.
”After his term though, Moore’s age will disqualify him from running for judge,” notes Alabama Public Radio, which adds that Moore could file an appeal to send his case to the state’s supreme court.

Even after the 2015 ruling of the U S Supreme Court ending marriage bans and a federal court order applying that decision to Alabama’s ban directly, Moore issued an order on Jan. 6, 2016, telling probate judges that prior state court orders supporting the state’s marriage ban remained in effect.

”Until further decision by the Alabama Supreme Court, the existing orders of the Alabama Supreme Court that Alabama probate judges have a ministerial duty not to issue any marriage license contrary to the Alabama Sanctity of Marriage Amendment or the Alabama Marriage Protection Act remain in full force and effect,” Moore wrote at the time.

But the   court also noted that the decision is based on a review of Moore’s behavior and decisions, not on the justices’ views of the Supreme Court’s June 2015 ruling that   couples have the right to marry  —   contrary to Alabama’s law, adopted in 2016, that had reserved marriage for heterosexual couples only.

Additionally, under state rules, Moore is not be eligible to run for another term as chief justice due to his age  —   although there is speculation that Moore could try, again, to run for governor of the state.

He was reelected to the bench in November 2012, and his   term runs through January 2019  —   at which point he will be unable to run for another term, as Alabama has age limits preventing anyone 70 or older from being elected or appointed as a judge.
He is 69 and will be ineligible to run for   because of his age.
His suspension without pay will last for the remainder of his   term in office, which ends in 2019.
The order also requires the head of Alabama’s highest court to pay the costs of the proceedings against him and stipulates that he will not be paid for the remainder of his   term.
Alabama’s top judge was suspended from the bench without pay for the remainder of his term, the state’s Court of the Judiciary said Friday.

Please follow the steps below, NEWS BRIEF An Alabama court indefinitely suspended Roy Moore, the state’s controversial chief justice, from office Friday for ordering probate judges to defy federal court rulings on   marriage bans.

’Read the order:’] WASHINGTON  —   Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore has been suspended from office without pay from the remainder of his term, the fallout from his action of telling probate judges in the state that they were not bound by federal court rulings guaranteeing equal marriage rights to   couples.
(CNN) Alabama’s chief justice Roy Moore was suspended without pay Friday for the rest of his term for directing probate judges to enforce the state’s ban on   marriage.

Saying that Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore violated judicial ethics when he ordered judges not to respect the U S Supreme Court’s landmark ruling on   marriage, Alabama’s Court of the Judiciary suspended Moore for the rest of his term in office.
“There is no meaningful difference between suspension for the remaining of the term and removal from office,” Mat Staver, Moore’s lawyer from Liberty Counsel, said in a statement.
”The rule of law should trump political agendas,” said Mat Staver, Liberty Counsel chairman and one of Moore’s attorneys.
“To suspend Chief Justice Moore for the rest of his term is the same as removal,” Mat Staver, founder and chairman of Liberty Counsel, said in a statement.
In 2003, a federal judge ordered Moore to remove a   granite monument of the Ten Commandments he had installed in the state   building.

The chief justice made national headlines in 2003 when he defied a federal court order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from a public judicial building on the grounds that it was an unconstitutional endorsement of religion.

This is the second time Roy S Moore, chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, has been effectively pulled from office, following his ouster in 2003 over his refusal to obey judicial rulings ordering him to remove a Ten Commandments statue from the Alabama Judicial Building.
In 2003, he was removed from office after refusing a federal court’s order to remove a prominent display of the Ten Commandments from the state judicial building.

In a   judgment Friday, two days after Moore appeared for a hearing in the case, Alabama’s Court of the Judiciary found him guilty of failing to comply with the law, uphold the integrity of the court and “perform the duties of his office impartially.
The Court of the Judiciary heard the complaint, with the   body unanimously finding Moore guilty of all six charges brought against him.
The Alabama Court of the Judiciary found Moore guilty on all six counts filed against him, including failure to “uphold the integrity and independence of the judiciary.
Moore refused, and the Court of the Judiciary removed him from office.
” Moore, a father of four, was removed from office in 2003 after he refused to remove the Ten Commandments monument he had installed in a judicial building in Montgomery.
Moore previously was removed from office in 2003 when he refused to follow a federal court’s order that he remove a display of the Ten Commandments from the courtroom.
